Hymenolepis nana The clinical history and stool microscopy indicate an infection with Hymenolepis nana. Its eggs have a thin outer membrane, an inner embryophore containing a hexacanth oncosphere, and are filled with yolk granules. These non-bile stained eggs float in a saturated salt solution.

questions.text: 60 year old male patient having miosis, ptosis, anhydrosis on left side and difficulty in walking. Patient also gives complaints of dysphagia, dysarthria. On examination, you found that pain and temperature lost on right side of the body and left side of face. What is probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Left lateral medullary syndrome, 
also known as Wallenberg syndrome. This condition is caused by a lesion in the lateral part of the medulla, often due to a vertebral artery or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) infarction. The clinical features described—miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis on the left side (indicative of Horner’s syndrome), dysphagia, dysarthria, and loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the body and left side of the face—are classic for lateral medullary syndrome. The loss of pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side of the body and same side of the face is due to the involvement of the spinothalamic tract and the trigeminal nerve in this region. Horner’s syndrome is associated with the disruption of sympathetic pathways, which are affected in lateral medullary syndrome.

The other options are incorrect for the following reasons:

(A) Left medial medullary syndrome: This syndrome is caused by a lesion in the medial part of the medulla, typically from occlusion of the vertebral artery. It causes contralateral hemiparesis, loss of proprioception and vibration sense on the opposite side of the body, and ipsilateral tongue weakness (due to hypoglossal nerve involvement). However, it does not present with Horner's syndrome or the pain and temperature loss described here.

(C) Right lateral medullary syndrome: A right lateral medullary syndrome would involve the opposite side of the body for pain and temperature loss, as well as ipsilateral face involvement. However, the symptoms described (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis on the left side) point to a lesion on the left side of the medulla, making this diagnosis less likely.

(D) Right medial medullary syndrome: This would present with features like contralateral hemiparesis, loss of proprioception and vibration on the opposite side of the body, and tongue weakness. It does not explain the Horner's syndrome (which involves the sympathetic pathways) or the sensory loss pattern (which is not typical for medial medullary syndrome).

questions.text: All of the following are adverse effects of thalidomide except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Myocarditis. Thalidomide is an immunomodulatory and anti-angiogenic drug primarily used in the treatment of multiple myeloma and erythema nodosum leprosum. While it has several well-documented adverse effects, myocarditis is not a recognized side effect of thalidomide. Myocarditis, which refers to inflammation of the heart muscle, is typically associated with viral infections, autoimmune conditions, or certain medications, but thalidomide has not been linked to causing this condition.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:
(B) Constipation:
Thalidomide has a well-known side effect of causing gastrointestinal issues, particularly constipation. This occurs due to its sedative properties, which can lead to reduced gut motility, slowing the passage of stool through the intestines.

(C) Peripheral Neuropathy:
One of the most significant adverse effects of thalidomide is peripheral neuropathy, which can manifest as numbness, tingling, or pain in the extremities. This occurs due to the drug’s neurotoxic effects, which damage peripheral nerves, and can sometimes be irreversible with prolonged use.

(D) Sedation:
Thalidomide was originally developed as a sedative, and its CNS depressant effects are still observed as a side effect. Patients taking thalidomide often experience drowsiness, fatigue, or dizziness, making sedation one of its prominent adverse effects.

choices.text: Insertion of abdominal drain followed by laparotomy

questions.text: A patient with abdominal injury presents to the emergency department with signs of signs of peritonitis and shock. Airway and breathing were secured and IV fluids were started with 2 large bore cannulas. The next line of management should be:  (LQ)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 


 This case scenario describes a patient who has developed peritonitis after a blunt abdominal trauma and the only reason for this has to be breach in the bowel integrity due to trauma and spillage of the intra bowel contents into peritoneal cavity leading to peritonitis. If this is a presentation you don’t need to any test in this patient, just take the patient straight away for an exploratory laparotomy. 
 Option A is false as even if you do FAST in this patient your management is not going to change, you will just end up delaying the management of the patient. 
 Option C is false as this might deteriorate the patient even futher as we are not addressing the actual cause of peritonitis
 Option D is false as laparoscopy has no role in management of a patient with acute abdominal trauma.

questions.text: All are indicators of malignancy in a mammography except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
In mammography we see the architecture of the tissue, pattern of calcification and characteristic of the mass to arrive at the diagnosis and categorize the lesion as benign or malignant. 
Nodular calcification or macrocalcifiction is not indicative of breast carcinoma. But if you see speckled margin, attenuated architecture, irregular mass these findings are suggestive of breast carcinoma.  

Malignant mammographic findings:


 Ill-defined margin, irregular stellate speculation.
 Comet tail, high density.
 Heterogenous mass.
 Wide halo.
 Microcalcification (< 0.5 mm size).
 Architectural distortion.
 Thickened skin.
 Thickened cooper ligament,
 Obiterated subcutaneous retromammary space.
 New or spiculated masses
 Clustered microcalcifications in linear or branching array

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the genetic counselor due to the family history of MEN-2B. His father died of medullary thyroid carcinoma. His genetic testing was positive for the RET protooncogene mutation. Which of the following will be the best line of management that will improve the prognosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Patients at risk for MEN 2A or MEN 2B, or with a positive family history, should be screened annually for:
- Pheochromocytoma: Urine VMA
- Hyperparathyroidism: Serum calcium
- Medullary carcinoma: Serum calcitonin
Routine RET mutation testing is recommended for at-risk family members. Prophylactic thyroidectomy is advised before age 6 for MEN2A and before age 1 for MEN2B.

questions.text: Statin-induced myopathy is not exacerbated by which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Enalapril. Enalapril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, is used for hypertension and heart failure. It does not interfere with statin metabolism or muscle function, making it unlikely to exacerbate statin-induced myopathy. Unlike drugs that inhibit statin metabolism via cytochrome P450 enzymes or have direct myotoxic effects, enalapril does not affect muscle metabolism or increase statin-related side effects. In fact, ACE inhibitors may have some protective effects on skeletal muscle, reducing inflammation and fibrosis. Therefore, enalapril does not contribute to an increased risk of statin-induced muscle toxicity.

Incorrect Options:
(A) Clofibrate: Clofibrate, a fibrate class drug, is used for lowering triglycerides. When combined with statins, fibrates significantly increase the risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis due to overlapping effects on muscle metabolism. Both drug classes can disrupt muscle cell integrity and lead to increased muscle damage.

(B) Nicotinic Acid: Also known as niacin, this lipid-lowering agent can enhance the risk of statin-induced myopathy. Niacin can cause muscle toxicity, especially when used in high doses with statins, due to its metabolic effects on lipid and energy pathways in muscle cells.

(C) Erythromycin: Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that inhibits the cytochrome P450 3A4 (CYP3A4) enzyme, which is responsible for metabolizing many statins. This inhibition leads to increased statin plasma levels, heightening the risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis. Therefore, erythromycin exacerbates statin-induced muscle toxicity by prolonging statin activity in the body.

questions.text: A third degree circumferential burn in the arm and forearm region, which of the following is most important for monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
When deep  second- and  third-degree burn wounds  encompass  the  circumference  of an extremity, peripheral circulation to the limb can be compromised. 

Development of generalized edema beneath a non-yielding eschar impedes venous outflow  and affects arterial inflow to the distal beds. 

This can be recognized by numbness and tingling in the limb and increased pain in digits.

Arterial flow can be assessed by determination of Doppler signals in the digital arteries and the palmar and plantar arches in affected extremities.

Capillary refill can also be assessed. 

Extremities at risk are identified either on clinical examination or by measurement of tissue pressures >40 mm Hg. 

These  extremities  require escharotomies (release of  the  burn eschar  by  incising  the  lateral  and  medial aspects  of  the extremity).

questions.text: What is the first-line treatment for a patient presenting with the finding shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ivermectin This image shows a serpiginous, erythematous, raised lesion on the skin, characteristic of Cutaneous Larva Migrans, also known as "Creeping Eruption." Ivermectin is the first-line drug for the treatment of cutaneous larva migrans.

questions.text:
A 20 year old male presented to ortho OPD with chronic pain and swelling palpable in the knee. An Xray was performed given below.

Identify the pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Osteochondroma

Here we can see a bony stalk with cartilaginous cap’ with involvement of distal femur. So we are dealing with osteochondroma or exostosis.

questions.text: Propanolol is useful in the treatment of all of the following EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Partial atrioventricular block.

Propranolol, a non-selective β-blocker, is contraindicated in patients with partial atrioventricular (AV) block because it slows conduction through the AV node. This can worsen AV block, potentially leading to complete heart block and severe bradycardia. Since AV block involves impaired electrical conduction from the atria to the ventricles, further depression of conduction by propranolol is harmful rather than therapeutic.

Incorrect Options:
(B) Angina – Incorrect.
Propranolol is useful in the treatment of angina pectoris. By blocking β1-receptors in the heart, it reduces heart rate, myocardial contractility, and oxygen demand, helping to relieve symptoms of angina and prevent ischemic episodes.

(C) Idiopathic hypertrophic subaortic cardiomyopathy (IHSS) – Incorrect.
Propranolol is beneficial in idiopathic hypertrophic subaortic cardiomyopathy (IHSS), also known as hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). It reduces heart rate and myocardial contractility, decreasing left ventricular outflow obstruction and improving diastolic filling. This helps in managing symptoms like exertional dyspnea, syncope, and palpitations.

(D) Familial tremor – Incorrect.
Propranolol is one of the first-line treatments for essential (familial) tremor. Its β2-blocking effect reduces tremor amplitude, providing significant symptomatic relief. This is particularly useful in upper limb tremors affecting daily activities such as writing and eating.

questions.text: Most common nosocomial infection is ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• A. Surgical site infection

o Common in postoperative patients.

o Important nosocomial infection, but not the most common overall.

• B. Respiratory tract infection

o Includes ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

o A major cause of morbidity and mortality in ICU patients.

o However, less frequent than UTI in overall hospital population.

• C. Urinary tract infection 

o Most common nosocomial infection.

o Majority are catheter-associated UTIs (CAUTI) due to prolonged use of indwelling urinary catheters.

o Contributes to about 30–40% of all hospital-acquired infections.

• D. Skin and soft tissue infection

o Can occur in burns, IV line insertion sites, or pressure sores.

o Less common compared to UTI or pneumonia.

choices.text: It is an inhibitor of fatty acid oxidation
lt improves tissue perfusion by modifying rheological property of blood
It is a novel sodium channel blocker

questions.text: True statement about trimetazidine is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

It is an inhibitor of fatty acid oxidation. Trimetazidine is a metabolic anti-ischemic agent that works by inhibiting 3-ketoacyl CoA thiolase (3-KAT), an enzyme involved in fatty acid β-oxidation. By shifting myocardial energy metabolism from fatty acid oxidation to glucose oxidation, trimetazidine enhances ATP production efficiency under ischemic conditions. This reduces oxygen consumption and oxidative stress, making it useful in conditions like stable angina, heart failure, and ischemic heart disease.

Incorrect Options:

(B) It improves tissue perfusion by modifying the rheological property of blood – Incorrect. Trimetazidine does not affect blood viscosity or rheological properties. Instead, it directly optimizes myocardial metabolism without causing changes in blood flow or vascular resistance. Drugs like pentoxifylline influence blood rheology, but trimetazidine does not.

(C) It is a novel sodium channel blocker – Incorrect. Trimetazidine is not a sodium channel blocker. Instead, agents like ranolazine exert anti-anginal effects by inhibiting late sodium channels, reducing intracellular calcium overload and improving myocardial relaxation.

(D) Both (A) and (B) are correct – Incorrect. Since option (B) is incorrect, this choice is also incorrect.

questions.text: An athlete suffers a fracture as shown in the knee X-ray below. How is this fracture managed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tension band wiring

Ref: Apley’s system of ORthopedics and Fractures 9/e pg887-888

The tension band technique converts a tensile force into a compressive force.
Enables improved fracture healing, as stability is improved when tensile forces are reduced at the fracture site.

choices.text: Reversal of blood flow in the ipsilateral vertebral artery
Reversal of blood flow in the contralateral carotid artery
Reversal of blood flow in the contralateral vertebral artery
Bilateral reversal of the flow in the vertebral arteries

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding subclavian steal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Subclavian steal syndrome (SSS), also called subclavian steal phenomenon or subclavian steal steno-occlusive disease, is a constellation of signs and symptoms that arise from retrograde (reversed) blood flow in the vertebral artery or the internal thoracic artery, due to a proximal stenosis (narrowing) and/or occlusion of the subclavian artery. The arm may be supplied by blood flowing in a retrograde direction down the vertebral artery at the expense of the vertebrobasilar circulation. This is called the subclavian steal. It is more severe than typical vertebrobasilar insufficiency.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male has typical symptoms of GERD refractory to medical management and is referred to your clinic to discuss surgical options. He has previously had a distal pancreatectomy/splenectomy from a gunshot wound and three subsequent laparotomies for adhesive bowel obstruction. What surgical option allows for satisfactory control of reflux while avoiding the abdomen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

The Belsey Mark-IV operation recreates the LES while reducing an intrathoracic stomach and closing a hiatal defect. This operation is approached via a left thoracotomy, allowing the surgeon to avoid a hostile abdomen 

This approach can also be useful in the dissection of large and giant chronic paraesophageal hernias.

The Belsey Mark-IV provides a 240-degree partial wrap, imbricating cardia against the distal esophagus.

Each of the other operations requires an abdominal approach.

The Toupet is a 270-degree, posterior partial wrap,

while the Dor is a 180-degree anterior partial wrap.

The Hill operation focuses on the creation of a gastroesophageal flap valve in an attempt to recreate normal anatomy.

questions.text: Post-mortem caloricity may be seen in all of the following causes of death except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Barbiturates poisoning

The temperature of the body remains raised for the first two hours up to 1.50C to 20C after death, known as post-mortem caloricity.

Conditions resulting in postmortem caloricity:

1.    Disturbance of heat regulation

•  Sunstroke

•  Pontine haemorrhage

2.    Increased production of heat due to muscular activity

•  Tetanus

•  Strychnine

•  Violent asphyxial deaths (Struggle prior to death)

3.    Excessive bacterial activity

•  Septicaemia

•  Cholera

•  Influenza etc.

4.    Miscellaneous

•  Alcohol, Heroin, Cocaine, CO poisoning

•  High atmospheric temp., Drug reactions, Fat/Air embolism

questions.text:
Indications for needle aspiration in liver abscess are: 

A. Recurrent
B. Left lobe
C. Refractory to treatment after 48-72 hours
D. >10 cms size
E. Multiple
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

B & D

Option A is false as recurrent liver abscess is not an indication of percutaneous aspiration.

Option B is correct as left lobe abscess are more likely to rupture hence they are an indication of aspiration.

Option C is false as the cutoff for aspiration of liver abscess is 3-5 days and not 48 to 72 hours of failure of medical management.

Option D is correct as any abscess > 5 cm in size is unlikely to respond to medical treatment and so it is an indication of aspiration.

Option E is false as multiple liver abscess are difficult to aspirate and often lead to incomplete resolution so it is not an indication for percutaneous aspiration.

choices.text: Blocks uptake of choline into nerve terminals

questions.text: A 40 -year-old actress presents to the dermatologist for treatment to address her wrinkles. She complains that her right eyelid and forehead are “too droopy” and has a persistent head ache since her first Botox treatment 5 days ago. What is the mechanism of action for this treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Prevents release of cholinergic vesicles.

Botulinum toxin (Botox) works by inhibiting the release of acetylcholine (ACh) from presynaptic cholinergic neurons at the neuromuscular junction. It does this by cleaving SNARE proteins (e.g., SNAP-25, synaptobrevin, syntaxin), which are essential for vesicular fusion and neurotransmitter release. This prevents muscle contraction, leading to temporary paralysis of facial muscles and smoothing of wrinkles.

In this patient, the droopy eyelid (ptosis) and headache are likely due to excess spread of Botox to surrounding muscles, affecting levator palpebrae superioris and causing ptosis. Botox is commonly used in cosmetic dermatology for wrinkle reduction, but improper injection or diffusion of the toxin can cause unintended muscle weakness.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:
(A) Binds ?-receptors preventing activation
Incorrect because botulinum toxin does not act on adrenergic receptors.
Drugs that block ?-receptors include alpha blockers (e.g., prazosin, tamsulosin), which are used for hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
(B) Binds muscarinic receptors preventing activation
Incorrect because Botox does not block muscarinic receptors.
Muscarinic antagonists (e.g., atropine, scopolamine, ipratropium) block parasympathetic signaling, but Botox works at the presynaptic level, not on receptors.
(C) Blocks uptake of choline into nerve terminals
Incorrect because Botox does not interfere with choline transport into neurons.
Hemicholinium is a drug that blocks choline uptake, thereby depleting acetylcholine synthesis, but this is not the mechanism of Botox.

questions.text: High inguinal orchidectomy specimen showed tumor testis with involvement of epididymis without vascular invasion stage is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The pathological T (pT) stage for testicular tumors, as per the TNM classification system, defines the extent of local tumor invasion. In this case, the high inguinal orchidectomy specimen reveals a tumor confined to the testis and involving the epididymis, crucially, without any evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. This specific combination of features is the defining characteristic of a pT1 stage testicular tumor. A pT1 tumor is strictly limited to the testis and/or epididymis, and it does not demonstrate invasion into lymphovascular spaces within the testis or epididymis. It may, however, invade the tunica albuginea, the fibrous capsule surrounding the testis. The absence of vascular invasion is the key differentiator that keeps this tumor within the pT1 classification despite epididymal involvement.

Incorrect Options:

B. T2: A pT2 stage tumor, while still confined to the testis and epididymis, would be characterized by the presence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. Alternatively, pT2 can also be assigned if the tumor extends through the tunica albuginea and involves the tunica vaginalis. Since the case explicitly states "without vascular invasion," these criteria for pT2 are not met.

C. T3: A pT3 stage tumor signifies invasion into the spermatic cord. This means the tumor has extended beyond the confines of the testis and epididymis and has entered the spermatic cord structures. The description in the question does not mention any involvement of the spermatic cord, making T3 an incorrect option.

D. T4: A pT4 stage tumor indicates that the tumor has invaded the scrotum. This is the most extensive local invasion. The case description clearly limits the tumor's extent to the testis and epididymis, with no mention of scrotal involvement, thus ruling out T4.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A. Direct inguinal hernia

questions.text: Which of the following drug does not cause pulmonary fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Chloramphenicol. 
Chloramphenicol is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is primarily associated with bone marrow suppression, aplastic anemia, and gray baby syndrome. It does not cause pulmonary fibrosis, making it the correct choice. The primary toxicities of chloramphenicol affect the hematopoietic system rather than the lungs.

Incorrect Options:
(A) Bleomycin: Bleomycin is a chemotherapeutic agent used primarily for testicular cancer, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, and squamous cell carcinomas. It is one of the most well-known causes of pulmonary fibrosis, as it induces oxidative damage in lung tissues, leading to progressive fibrosis. The risk is dose-dependent, especially at cumulative doses >400 units.

(B) Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic drug (Class III) used for atrial fibrillation and ventricular arrhythmias. One of its severe adverse effects is pulmonary toxicity, which can lead to amiodarone-induced pulmonary fibrosis. This occurs due to its direct toxic effects on alveolar macrophages and lung parenchyma, leading to chronic interstitial lung disease.

(D) Methysergide: Methysergide is an ergot derivative previously used for migraine prophylaxis. However, it has been associated with retroperitoneal fibrosis, cardiac fibrosis, and pulmonary fibrosis, limiting its use. The fibrotic changes are due to its long-term serotonergic effects on connective tissues.

questions.text: A truck driver presented to the hospital with a minor soft tissue injury. Which of the following NSAID should not be prescribed to him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Indomethacin
Indomethacin is a potent non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that is commonly used for its strong anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties. However, it is not suitable for a truck driver because it has significant central nervous system (CNS) side effects, including dizziness, headache, confusion, and drowsiness. These effects can impair alertness and coordination, which are critical for someone operating heavy machinery like a truck. Given the risk of drowsiness and cognitive impairment, indomethacin should be avoided in this patient.

Incorrect Options:

(A) Celecoxib – Incorrect. Celecoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor with a lower risk of gastrointestinal (GI) side effects compared to non-selective NSAIDs. It does not significantly affect CNS function, making it a safer choice for a truck driver.

(B) Naproxen – Incorrect. Naproxen is a non-selective NSAID, but it has a lower risk of CNS side effects compared to indomethacin. While it can cause gastric irritation, it does not impair alertness as much as indomethacin. It is a reasonable choice for pain relief in a truck driver.

(C) Diclofenac sodium – Incorrect. Diclofenac is another non-selective NSAID, but it has less CNS toxicity than indomethacin. It is commonly used for musculoskeletal pain and soft tissue injuries and does not cause significant drowsiness, making it a better alternative.

questions.text: Reimplantation time for lower limb is upto ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Reimplantation time for extremities is 4 to 6 hours

Reimplantation time refers to the maximum period of warm ischemia beyond which limb survival and function become very poor.

• For lower limb amputations, the safe warm ischemia time is up to 6 hours.

• For upper limb amputations, it can be tolerated a little longer because of lesser muscle bulk.

• If the amputated part is preserved properly in cold (ice, not in direct contact), cold ischemia can extend viability up to 12–24 hours.

questions.text: What is true about nasal cannula
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Normally air has 0.21 or 21% Oxygen. 

  • A nasal cannula delivers low-flow oxygen.
  • Oxygen flow rate is usually 1–6 L/min.
  • Each additional 1 L/min flow increases FiO₂ by ~4%.
    • 1 L/min → ~24% FiO₂
    • 2 L/min → ~28% FiO₂
    • 3 L/min → ~32% FiO₂
    • 4 L/min → ~36% FiO₂
    • 5 L/min → ~40% FiO₂
    • 6 L/min → ~44% FiO₂

questions.text: E-cadherin is more often mutated in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lauren's Classification of Gastric Cancer :

  • E-cadherin (CDH1 gene) is a cell adhesion molecule important for maintaining intercellular junctions.
  • Mutation or loss of E-cadherin function causes cells to lose cohesion, leading to signet-ring cell morphology and infiltrative growth.
  • This is the hallmark of diffuse type gastric carcinoma (Lauren classification).
  • In contrast, intestinal type gastric carcinoma is more often associated with chronic gastritis, intestinal metaplasia, and H. pylori infection rather than E-cadherin mutations.

questions.text: A 28 year old travel blogger presents to you for taking an advice and tells you that he is planning a short trip to an area which is known to be malaria endemic. Which is the most appropriate intervention for malaria prophylaxis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) recommends chemoprophylaxis for selective groups in high P. falciparum endemic areas. Use of personal protection measures including Insecticide Treated bed Nets (ITN) / Long Lasting Insecticidal Nets (LLIN) is encouraged for pregnant women and other vulnerable population including travellers for longer stay. However, for longer stay of Military and Para-military forces in high P. falciparum endemic areas, the practice of chemoprophylaxis should be followed wherever appropriate, e.g. troops on night patrol duty, and decisions of their Medical Administrative Authority should be followed.

For Short Term Prophylaxis (less than 6 weeks): Doxycycline, 100 mg daily in adults and 1.5 mg/kg for children more than 8 years old; it should be started 2 days before travel and continued for 4 weeks after leaving the malarious area. Doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnant women and children less than 8 years.

For long-term chemoprophylaxis (more than 6 weeks): Mefloquine 5 mg/kg bw (up to 250 mg) weekly; it should be administered two weeks before, during and four weeks after leaving the area. Mefloquine is contraindicated in cases with history of convulsions, neuropsychiatric problems and cardiac conditions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaint of recurrent urinary tract infections, she now has three consecutive UTIs in a 4-month period. Each time, the culture and sensitivity reveal resistance to ciprofloxacin. What is the most likely source of resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

DNA gyrase.

Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that works by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II) and topoisomerase IV, enzymes essential for DNA replication and supercoiling. Bacterial resistance to ciprofloxacin often occurs due to mutations in the DNA gyrase (gyrA and gyrB genes), which prevent ciprofloxacin from binding effectively. Efflux pumps and plasmid-mediated resistance (qnr genes) can also contribute, but the most common mechanism remains mutations in DNA gyrase.

This patient has recurrent UTIs with cultures showing ciprofloxacin resistance, suggesting that the uropathogens have developed mutations in DNA gyrase, leading to fluoroquinolone treatment failure.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:
(B) DNA polymerase
Incorrect because DNA polymerase is responsible for DNA replication but is not a target of ciprofloxacin.
Fluoroquinolones do not interfere with DNA synthesis at the polymerization stage but rather at the supercoiling and unwinding stage.
(C) DNA topoisomerase I
Incorrect because topoisomerase I relaxes negative supercoils and is not the primary target of ciprofloxacin.
Fluoroquinolones specifically target DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II) and topoisomerase IV, not topoisomerase I.
(D) DNA topoisomerase II
Incorrect terminology in this context.
DNA gyrase is a type of topoisomerase II, but in bacteria, the primary term used is DNA gyrase when referring to ciprofloxacin resistance.
Mutations in DNA gyrase (a form of topoisomerase II) are the direct cause of ciprofloxacin resistance.

choices.text: It is the drug of choice in non-traumatic rhabdomyolysis
It has a long duration of action
It may induce life threatening hyperkalemia
It is useful in patients with spinal cord injuries with paraplegia

questions.text: 0ne of the following statements about succinylcholine is true
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It may induce life-threatening hyperkalemia. Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that causes persistent depolarization of the neuromuscular junction by binding to nicotinic receptors. This sustained depolarization leads to an efflux of potassium (K?) from skeletal muscle cells, which can result in severe hyperkalemia. In normal individuals, this potassium increase is mild, but in certain conditions—such as burn injuries, neuromuscular disorders, spinal cord injuries, paraplegia, muscular dystrophies, or severe trauma—it can be life-threatening, potentially leading to fatal cardiac arrhythmias. Because of this risk, succinylcholine should be avoided in patients at high risk of hyperkalemia.

Incorrect Options:
(A) It is the drug of choice in non-traumatic rhabdomyolysis – Incorrect. Succinylcholine should never be used in patients with rhabdomyolysis, as these individuals already have muscle breakdown and elevated potassium levels. Administering succinylcholine in this setting can exacerbate hyperkalemia and precipitate life-threatening cardiac events. Instead, non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers (e.g., rocuronium or vecuronium) are preferred.

(B) It has a long duration of action – Incorrect. Succinylcholine has a very short duration of action, typically lasting 5–10 minutes due to rapid hydrolysis by plasma butyrylcholinesterase (pseudocholinesterase). However, in individuals with pseudocholinesterase deficiency, its effects can be prolonged, leading to prolonged paralysis.

(D) It is useful in patients with spinal cord injuries with paraplegia – Incorrect. Patients with spinal cord injuries and paraplegia develop upregulation of acetylcholine receptors in denervated muscles. When succinylcholine is administered, this can lead to excessive potassium release, resulting in severe hyperkalemia and fatal cardiac arrhythmias. Therefore, succinylcholine should be avoided in such patients, and alternative non-depolarizing agents should be used instead.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic.crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Barberio test The test done in the scenario is the Barberio test. It is used to detect seminal fluid. When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

questions.text: A patient with severe eosinophilic asthma is treated with a recently approved monoclonal antibody that targets IL-5. What is the name of this medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All of the above.

Mepolizumab, benralizumab, and reslizumab are all monoclonal antibodies approved for the treatment of severe eosinophilic asthma, targeting the interleukin-5 (IL-5) pathway to reduce eosinophil levels and inflammation.

A. Mepolizumab:

Mepolizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that binds directly to IL-5, preventing it from interacting with its receptor on eosinophils. This inhibition reduces the production and survival of eosinophils, thereby decreasing airway inflammation associated with severe eosinophilic asthma. Mepolizumab is administered via subcutaneous injection. 
EN.WIKIPEDIA.ORG

B. Benralizumab:

Benralizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-5 receptor alpha subunit (IL-5R?) on eosinophils and basophils. By binding to IL-5R?, benralizumab not only blocks IL-5 signaling but also induces antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity, leading to rapid and near-complete depletion of eosinophils. This dual action helps control severe eosinophilic asthma. Benralizumab is administered via subcutaneous injection. 
AACIJOURNAL.BIOMEDCENTRAL.COM

C. Reslizumab:

Reslizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that binds to IL-5, similar to mepolizumab, thereby inhibiting its interaction with the IL-5 receptor on eosinophils. This action reduces eosinophil levels and associated inflammation in severe eosinophilic asthma. Reslizumab is administered via intravenous infusion.

questions.text: Metformin is NOT effective in lowering of blood sugar level in which of the following patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Non-diabetics.

Metformin is not effective in lowering blood sugar levels in non-diabetic individuals because its glucose-lowering effect depends on the presence of hyperglycemia.

Metformin works by decreasing hepatic gluconeogenesis (glucose production by the liver) and improving insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues (muscles and adipose tissue).
In non-diabetics, blood glucose levels are already regulated by normal insulin function, and since metformin does not stimulate insulin secretion, it does not lower glucose levels in those with normal glucose metabolism.
Additionally, it does not cause hypoglycemia in non-diabetics, unlike insulin or sulfonylureas, which can force glucose levels to drop even when they are normal.
Thus, metformin has no significant glucose-lowering effect in non-diabetics, making option C the correct answer.

Incorrect Options:
A. Type 2 Diabetics – Incorrect

Metformin is the first-line drug for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
It reduces blood glucose levels by improving insulin sensitivity and decreasing hepatic glucose output.
It is highly effective in lowering blood sugar in type 2 diabetics, especially those with insulin resistance.
B. Obese Diabetic – Incorrect

Metformin is particularly beneficial in obese diabetics because it does not cause weight gain, unlike insulin or sulfonylureas.
It also helps with weight loss by reducing appetite and improving metabolism.
Thus, it is an effective and preferred choice for overweight or obese type 2 diabetics.
D. Diabetics not responding to sulfonylureas – Incorrect

Metformin can be effective in patients who do not respond to sulfonylureas (e.g., due to insulin resistance).
Sulfonylureas work by stimulating insulin secretion from the pancreas, but if insulin resistance is the main problem, metformin can help improve glucose control by increasing insulin sensitivity.
It is often used in combination with sulfonylureas for better glycemic control.

questions.text: All of the following are limitations of typical tricyclic antidepressants EXCET
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Low oral bioavailability

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) do not have low oral bioavailability. In fact, TCAs are well absorbed after oral administration, with good systemic availability despite significant first-pass metabolism in the liver. The bioavailability of most TCAs is moderate to high, allowing them to exert their therapeutic effects effectively.

Thus, low oral bioavailability is NOT a limitation of TCAs, making Option A the correct answer.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:
Option B (Narrow safety margin):

TCAs have a low therapeutic index, meaning that the difference between a therapeutic dose and a toxic dose is small.
Overdose can cause life-threatening toxicity, including arrhythmias, seizures, and coma, making safety a major concern.
Option C (Frequent side effects):

TCAs have multiple side effects due to their action on various receptors:
Anticholinergic effects: Dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision, urinary retention.
Alpha-1 blockade: Orthostatic hypotension.
H1 receptor blockade: Sedation and weight gain.
Cardiotoxicity: Prolonged QT interval and arrhythmias.
These side effects limit their use compared to newer antidepressants like SSRIs.
Option D (Long latent period for response):

TCAs, like most antidepressants, have a delayed onset of action.
It typically takes 2-4 weeks for clinical improvement to be seen, which can be frustrating for patients and clinicians.
This long latent period is a well-known limitation of TCAs.

questions.text: Agonistic action at which of the following adrenergic receptors results in the reduction of aqueous secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A2 receptor. Agonistic action at A2-adrenergic receptors results in a reduction of aqueous humor secretion, leading to decreased intraocular pressure. A2-receptors are located on the ciliary body epithelium and sympathetic nerve terminals, where their activation inhibits norepinephrine release, reducing A-receptor-mediated stimulation of aqueous humor production. This mechanism is utilized by alpha-2 agonists like brimonidine and apraclonidine, which are used in glaucoma treatment to lower intraocular pressure.

Incorrect Options:

(A) B1 receptor – Incorrect.
β1-adrenergic receptors stimulate aqueous humor production by increasing cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels in the ciliary epithelium. Activation of ?? receptors leads to increased aqueous humor secretion, which would worsen glaucoma rather than help treat it. This is why ??-blockers like betaxolol are used in glaucoma therapy to reduce aqueous humor production.

(C) B2 receptor – Incorrect.
β2 receptors are also present in the ciliary body and have a similar effect as β2 receptors. Activation of β2 receptors increases aqueous humor production, which is counterproductive in glaucoma treatment. Blocking β2 receptors with non-selective β-blockers like timolol helps lower intraocular pressure.

(D) M2 receptor – Incorrect.
M2 receptors are muscarinic cholinergic receptors, primarily found in cardiac and smooth muscle. While muscarinic agonists (like pilocarpine) can reduce intraocular pressure, this occurs by enhancing trabecular outflow rather than decreasing aqueous humor production. M2 receptors do not play a significant direct role in reducing aqueous secretion.

questions.text: Aconite poisoning causes all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increased BP

Signs and symptoms of Aconite (Sweet Poison/Meetha Zehar) are:

• Tingling and numbness in the mouth and later all over the body

• Salivation, dysphagia, 

• Profuse sweating, subnormal temperature,

• Hypotension,

• Initial tachycardia followed by bradycardia.

• Alternate dilatation and contraction of pupil, called HIPPUS.

questions.text: True statement about Bankarts lesion in recurrent anterior dislocation of shoulder:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Injury to anterior inferior glenoid labrum

A Bankart lesion specifically refers to a tear or avulsion of the anterior inferior portion of the glenoid labrum. This injury occurs when the humeral head dislocates anteriorly, often in a traumatic event or recurrent dislocations, leading to detachment of the labrum from the glenoid rim. This disruption compromises the stability of the shoulder joint by impairing the function of the inferior glenohumeral ligament complex, which is crucial for maintaining the congruence of the joint. The precise involvement of the anterior inferior labrum is what defines the Bankart lesion and distinguishes it from other shoulder injuries.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – Injury of anterior superior glenoid labrum
This option is incorrect because the injury in a Bankart lesion is not located at the anterior superior labrum. Injuries to the superior labrum are typically associated with SLAP (Superior Labrum Anterior and Posterior) lesions, which have a different mechanism and clinical presentation compared to Bankart lesions.

Option C – Depression in posteroinferior head of humerus
This option is not correct. The depression described here does not correspond with a Bankart lesion. Instead, Hill-Sachs lesions—impaction fractures caused by the humeral head impacting against the glenoid rim during dislocation—are usually found on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head, not posteroinferior.

Option D – Depression in the posterosuperior part of head of humerus
This statement is also incorrect because it misidentifies the location and nature of the typical osseous defect associated with shoulder dislocations. A Bankart lesion involves soft tissue damage at the glenoid rim, specifically the anterior inferior part, rather than a depression in any part of the humeral head. The location given in this option does not relate to any classic findings in anterior shoulder instability.

questions.text: Klippel trenaunay syndrome is associated with all of the following except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Klippel–Trénaunay syndrome formerly Klippel–Trénaunay–Weber syndrome is a rare congenital medical condition in which blood vessels and/or lymph vessels fail to form properly. The three main features are nevus flammeus (port-wine stain), venous and lymphatic malformations, and soft-tissue hypertrophy of the affected limb. The classical triad of Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome consists of:

  • vascular malformations of the capillary, venous and lymphatic vessels;
  • varicosities of unusual distribution, particularly the lateral venous anomaly; and
  • unilateral soft and skeletal tissue hypertrophy, usually the lower extremity.
