questions.text: Which one the following  does not require treatment with anti-D during the first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Threatened abortion.

Anti-D immunoglobulin is not routinely required for a threatened abortion in the first trimester unless there is significant vaginal bleeding or a confirmed fetal loss. In most cases of threatened abortion where the pregnancy continues and there is minimal risk of feto-maternal hemorrhage (FMH), anti-D prophylaxis is not necessary. However, it may be given in cases of significant bleeding or if miscarriage occurs.

Reasons Why the Other Options Require Anti-D:

A) Ectopic Pregnancy
 • Anti-D is required in Rh-negative women after an ectopic pregnancy because of the risk of feto-maternal hemorrhage, even though the pregnancy is outside the uterus.

B) Evacuation of Partial Mole
 • Anti-D is indicated after the evacuation of a partial mole in Rh-negative women because the molar tissue may contain Rh-positive cells, which can lead to sensitization.

C) Evacuation of RPOC (Retained Products of Conception)
 • Anti-D is required after the evacuation of RPOC in Rh-negative women to prevent sensitization due to the presence of fetal cells that might enter the maternal circulation.

Anti-D immunoglobulin is not required in certain scenarios where there is no risk of feto-maternal hemorrhage (FMH) or the fetus is confirmed to be Rh-negative. Below are the key situations:

1. Rh-Negative Father
 • If the biological father of the fetus is confirmed to be Rh-negative, the fetus will also be Rh-negative, eliminating the risk of Rh sensitization.

2. Confirmed Fetal Rh-Negative Status
 • If the fetus is confirmed to be Rh-negative through tests like cell-free fetal DNA or amniocentesis, anti-D is not necessary.

3. Threatened Abortion Without Significant Bleeding
 • In cases of threatened abortion with minimal or no vaginal bleeding and no evidence of miscarriage or FMH, anti-D is typically not required.

4. First-Trimester Events Without Significant Bleeding
 • Routine anti-D prophylaxis is not required for minor first-trimester events without significant risk of FMH, such as:
 • Uncomplicated miscarriage.
 • Minor spotting.

5. Pre-Existing Sensitization
 • If the mother is already sensitized to Rh-positive blood (as confirmed by a positive indirect Coombs test or high anti-D antibody titers), administering anti-D will not provide any benefit.

questions.text: A32 year old lady presented with sudden onset of right upper quadrant pain for past 1 day, on taking history her LMP was 20 days ago and it was normal in flow she also complained of pain during coitus 3 days ago and since then she also has lower abdominal pain. Per speculum examination the cervix and vagina look healthy but she has cervical motion tenderness. Her laparoscopy image is shown below what is the likely diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. This patient presents with right upper quadrant pain, lower abdominal pain, and cervical motion tenderness, all of which are key features of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is an inflammatory complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), where infection ascends to involve the peritoneal surface of the liver, causing perihepatitis. The pain in the right upper quadrant is a hallmark of this syndrome, and the presence of cervical motion tenderness and a history of pain during coitus (which suggests a recent pelvic infection) further supports this diagnosis. The laparoscopy image likely shows the typical findings of peritoneal inflammation around the liver capsule, a characteristic of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Now, let’s review why the other options are incorrect:

A. Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a condition characterized by mucinous ascites and peritoneal implants often arising from a mucinous ovarian tumor or appendiceal cancer. It typically presents with abdominal distension and vague abdominal pain, but it would not cause acute right upper quadrant pain or cervical motion tenderness as seen in this patient. The lack of a mass or signs of malignancy on examination also makes this diagnosis less likely.

B. Endometriosis can cause pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia (pain during coitus), but it is less likely to cause right upper quadrant pain. Endometriosis typically affects the pelvic organs, and while it can cause pain during intercourse and in the lower abdomen, it does not commonly present with cervical motion tenderness or perihepatitis. Additionally, endometriosis would not show the peritoneal inflammation seen on laparoscopy in this case.

C. Acute appendicitis often presents with right lower quadrant pain, not right upper quadrant pain. While acute appendicitis can cause general abdominal pain, it typically does not lead to cervical motion tenderness or the upper quadrant findings seen here. The patient's cervical motion tenderness and the absence of typical appendicitis symptoms (such as localized tenderness in the right lower quadrant) make this diagnosis unlikely.
